title: How to Make Decals Cheaply for Your 3DS

steps.headline: Think about what you want.
steps.description: Hate Pokémon? Then don't stick a Bulbasaur to your DS.

steps.headline: Think about where you're putting things.
steps.description: Most cheap stickers are permanent, and will probably leave a residue even if they aren't.

steps.headline: If you want to, cut off bits you don't like.
steps.description: But remember, if you make a total Trubbish of this, then you need a very steady hand to fix it.

steps.headline: When you want to remove the sticker, don't use anything that can damage the inner workings.
steps.description: Be careful, you don't want broken consoles on your conscience.

steps.headline: Take precautions.
steps.description: Most paints are not good news if you eat them.

steps.headline: Like with stickers, think about content before you apply.
steps.description: This time it's a good idea to do a dry run on some paper or waste plastic when you're ready.

steps.headline: Make a template.
steps.description: If you can't make one, print out a template from the internet. This saves time and more importantly, money.

steps.headline: Shield the other parts of your 3DS with some paper and masking tape, making sure that template is well stuck down if you made one.
Use appropriate brushes or spray cans.
steps.description: For best results with a spray, cover as much of the room up as possible, or do it outside. Then go hell for leather. For best results with a brush, do things slowly, with care, and don't get distracted.

steps.headline: Leave an appropriate time for your work to dry.
steps.description: It usually says how long on the can, but if you aren't convinced, leave overnight in a dry place at room temperature and return in the morning.

steps.headline: Don't try to remove the paint.
steps.description: The necessary equipment leaves marks, the stripper damages the electronics and the eBay value just skyrocketed on your one-of a-kind hand-painted 3DS. Not that you'd ever sell it.

steps.headline: Create a design you like or download one from the internet.
Some shops (like those which process photos or print t-shirts) will print this design onto some paper, fabric or a sticker.
steps.description: Go there and pay the attendant to do so.

steps.headline: After waiting, then you can peel off the sticker, or apply some strong glue to the paper or fabric.
steps.description: Immediately after, try to stick down your design evenly.

steps.headline: Be very careful- you have one shot at this, and you can't use any glue-removing solvents, otherwise it'll mess with your DS's tiny silicon mind.
If you do mess up, then send it to the Nintendo Repair Centre or an electronics shop with a shameful explanation that wouldn't fool a grunt in any video game.
steps.description: Pay up and if you want to try again, repeat steps 2-5 (only step 5 if you go wrong).

text: Dirt Cheap: Stickers Think about what you want. Hate Pokémon? Then don't stick a Bulbasaur to your DS. Think about where you're putting things. Most cheap stickers are permanent, and will probably leave a residue even if they aren't. If you want to, cut off bits you don't like. But remember, if you make a total Trubbish of this, then you need a very steady hand to fix it. When you want to remove the sticker, don't use anything that can damage the inner workings. Be careful, you don't want broken consoles on your conscience. Affordable: Paint Take precautions. Most paints are not good news if you eat them. Like with stickers, think about content before you apply. This time it's a good idea to do a dry run on some paper or waste plastic when you're ready. Make a template. If you can't make one, print out a template from the internet. This saves time and more importantly, money. Shield the other parts of your 3DS with some paper and masking tape, making sure that template is well stuck down if you made one.  Use appropriate brushes or spray cans. For best results with a spray, cover as much of the room up as possible, or do it outside. Then go hell for leather. For best results with a brush, do things slowly, with care, and don't get distracted. Leave an appropriate time for your work to dry. It usually says how long on the can, but if you aren't convinced, leave overnight in a dry place at room temperature and return in the morning. Don't try to remove the paint. The necessary equipment leaves marks, the stripper damages the electronics and the eBay value just skyrocketed on your one-of a-kind hand-painted 3DS. Not that you'd ever sell it. Wallet-Bothering: Printed Decal Create a design you like or download one from the internet.  Some shops (like those which process photos or print t-shirts) will print this design onto some paper, fabric or a sticker. Go there and pay the attendant to do so. After waiting, then you can peel off the sticker, or apply some strong glue to the paper or fabric. Immediately after, try to stick down your design evenly. Be very careful- you have one shot at this, and you can't use any glue-removing solvents, otherwise it'll mess with your DS's tiny silicon mind.  If you do mess up, then send it to the Nintendo Repair Centre or an electronics shop with a shameful explanation that wouldn't fool a grunt in any video game. Pay up and if you want to try again, repeat steps 2-5 (only step 5 if you go wrong).
